researchers_stance: V1 is a massive lift from baseline across every metric — conversion from 7% to 43%, resonance from 17% to 58%, clarity from 0% to 88% nailed_it. The brand voice is working. However, two critical gaps emerged: fomo_scroller has a 75% resonance / 17% conversion gap (they love the concept but the backward-looking copy doesn't serve their forward-looking need), and journal_graveyard is stuck at 17% (retention concerns are unsolved). Network believability at 62% is the breakout metric — this is the product's differentiator.
exec_summary: First real copy version tested. Identity-driven hero ('Your social life, ranked'), specific examples (8/10 Thai place), one-tap emphasis, network discovery section. All metrics lifted massively from baseline. Two structural gaps identified: fomo_scroller needs forward-looking reframe, journal_graveyard needs retention proof.
findings:
• +36pp conversion lift validates the baseline approach: V1 at 43% vs baseline 7%. The floor was real, the lift is real.
  • Network discovery is the breakout concept: 62% believability — highest metric. Friend-powered discovery resonates more than the personal journal framing.
  • Resonance-conversion gap in fomo_scroller: 75% resonance but only 17% conversion. They love the concept but the copy is backward-looking ('record what you did'). They need 'discover what to do next.'
  • Clarity at 88% nailed_it: The specific examples and Beli comparison communicate the product clearly. Major improvement from 0%.
  • Price perception improved: 'too expensive' dropped from 50% to 23%. Value framing makes $12/month feel justified.
recommendations:
1. Reframe hero for forward-looking discovery: Add 'discover what's next' to subhead for fomo_scroller.
  2. Add retention section: Address journal_graveyard's 'I'll abandon this in a week' concern directly.
  3. Address cold-start: Multiple buckets ask 'what if I'm the first of my friends?' Add pre-network value paragraph.
  4. Soften paywall: Social features behind Pro creates a catch-22. Add basic friend activity to free.
  5. Add referral incentive: Align business model with network growth.
qualitative_themes:
• Memory framing lands universally (28 mentions): 'Hundreds of places, remember twenty' is the most-cited problem statement.
  • 'One tap' is critical (22 mentions): Especially for journal_graveyard. The effortlessness claim is the entry point.
  • Network discovery excites (31 mentions): 'Friends' picks over algorithms' is the differentiator personas respond to most.
  • Cold-start concern (15 mentions): 'What if none of my friends use this?' across 4 of 5 buckets.
  • Social paywall objection (12 mentions): 'Don't gate the social features behind Pro — the network can't grow.'
clarity_notes: 88% nailed_it, 10% partial, 2% wrong. Major improvement. The Beli comparison and specific examples communicate the product clearly.
appendix_notes: V1 uses the same audience as baseline (audience_v1.json). All deltas are directly comparable.

bucket_deep_dives.taste_curator:
58% conversion — strong start

The specific rating examples (8/10 Thai place) proved the team 'gets it.' Taste analytics in Pro need more specificity.

Key personas: High-skepticism personas still cite 'need to see the interface.'

Risk: Removing specific examples would hurt this bucket.
bucket_deep_dives.social_connector:
50% conversion — resonance-conversion gap

75% resonance but 50% conversion. They love the concept but worry friends won't join and social features are paywalled.

Key personas: Social evangelists who need a free social tier and a referral incentive to convert.

Risk: If paywall isn't softened, this bucket plateaus.
bucket_deep_dives.journal_graveyard:
17% conversion — toughest bucket

Down from 58% dealbreakers (baseline) to 25%, which is progress. But retention fears dominate. They need to believe this time will be different.

Key personas: Every persona cites past app abandonment. Copy must acknowledge this directly.

Risk: May be a structural 50% ceiling bucket. Copy can reduce friction but can't change behavior.
bucket_deep_dives.fomo_scroller:
17% conversion — biggest gap, biggest opportunity

75% resonance proves the audience is right. 17% conversion proves the framing is wrong. They need forward-looking discovery ('what to do next'), not backward-looking recording ('rate what you did').

Key personas: 'V1 told me to record my life. I need help upgrading it.'

Risk: If V2 doesn't add forward-looking framing, this bucket stays at 17%.
bucket_deep_dives.city_explorer:
75% conversion — strongest bucket

Highest conversion, lowest dealbreakers (8%). The product-audience fit is strong. Cold-start concern is the main friction.

Key personas: Recently relocated, actively building their city map.

Risk: Cold-start must be addressed to push above 75%.
